item.title: The Day the Music Died
item.dc:creator: foraslanandthevolunteerstate
item.description: Since childhood, Don McLean‘s “American Pie” has been one of my favorite songs. My parents raised me with good music, not that 80s crap that a lot of my friends grew up with.  I grew up listening to my parents’ Beatles, Simon and Garfunkel, the Temptations, and Elvis records, along with a host of other [...]

item.title: Chinese New Year Celebrations
item.dc:creator: Lisa
item.description: Tonight we celebrated Chinese New Year with a little Chinese Banquet. We started with Pot Sticker Dumplings. These were delicious little pork dumplings initially cooked in a fry pan to create a crispy bottom. Boiling water is then poured into the pan, and the pan is partially covered with a lid to create a little [...]
item.content:encoded:
Tonight we celebrated Chinese New Year with a little Chinese Banquet.

We started with Pot Sticker Dumplings. These were delicious little pork dumplings initially cooked in a fry pan to create a crispy bottom. Boiling water is then poured into the pan, and the pan is partially covered with a lid to create a little steam room to complete the cooking process.  These little morsels were a huge hit with the kids.

Pot Sticker Dumplings
from taste.com.au
 
2 x 4cm pieces ginger, peeled
250g Chinese cabbage, finely shredded
350g minced pork
2 green onions, finely chopped
2 tbs soy sauce
1 tbs oyster sauce
2 tsp sesame oil 1 tbs Shaoxing rice wine* or dry sherry
Cornflour, for dusting
2 x 275g pkts gow gee pastries (wrappers)
1/3 cup (80ml) peanut oil
  1. Finely grate 1 piece of ginger, then finely shred second piece. Place cabbage in a bowl. Sprinkle with 1 tsp salt then leave for 30 minutes. Squeeze handfuls of cabbage to remove excess water then place in a bowl. Add 1 1/2 tsp grated ginger, minced pork, onions, sauces, sesame oil and wine and combine well.
  2. Line a large tray with baking paper then dust with cornflour. Using a finger, wet edge of a wrapper with a little water. Place 2 level tsp of filling in centre. Fold wrapper in half and, using your thumb and index finger, pleat one edge, then press edges together to seal. Place, in a single layer, on prepared tray. Repeat with remaining wrappers and filling. Dumplings can be made up to 6 hours in advance; store covered in the fridge.
  3. Preheat oven to 150°C. Heat 1 tbs peanut oil in a non-stick frying pan over medium-high heat. Add 12 dumplings, pleated side-up in a single layer, and cook for 1-2 minutes or until brown underneath. Carefully add 1/2 cup boiling water, then cover partially with a lid and cook for a further 4-5 minutes or until water has evaporated and dumplings are crisp underneath. Transfer to an oven tray, cover with foil and keep warm in oven. Repeat with remaining oil and dumplings.

Then, for main, we had Longevity Beef Noodles and Fried Rice.

 

I actually made the fried rice for the kids but they adored the noodles as well.

Longevity Beef Noodles
from taste.com.au

500g packet fresh thin egg noodles
2 teaspoons sesame oil
1/4 cup peanut oil
500g beef fillet, thinly sliced
2cm piece fresh ginger, peeled, finely grated
2 garlic cloves, crushed
150g snow peas, trimmed, cut finely lengthwise
1/2 cup chicken stock
2 tablespoons soy sauce
2 tablespoons oyster sauce
2 cups beansprouts, trimmed
1/4 teaspoon ground white pepper
fresh coriander leaves, to serve
  1. Place noodles in a heatproof bowl. Cover with boiling water. Stand for 5 minutes or until heated through. Separate with a fork. Drain. Return to bowl. Add sesame oil. Toss to combine.
  2. Heat a wok over high heat. Add 1 tablespoon peanut oil and swirl to coat. Add half the beef. Stir-fry for 2 to 3 minutes or until sealed. Remove to a plate. Repeat with 1 tablespoon oil and remaining beef.
  3. Heat remaining peanut oil in wok. Add ginger and garlic. Stir-fry for 1 minute. Add snow peas and half the stock. Stir-fry for 2 minutes or until liquid is reduced by half.
  4. Return beef and any juices to wok. Add noodles, soy sauce, oyster sauce, remaining stock, beansprouts and pepper. Stir-fry for 2 to 3 minutes or until heated through. Serve topped with coriander.

 Finally, we finished off with Egg Custart Tarts and (shop bought) Fortune Cookies.

Egg Custard Tarts
from taste.com.au

70g (1/3 cup) caster sugar
80ml (1/3 cup) water
2 eggs, lightly beaten
2 sheets (25 x 25cm) frozen butter puff pastry, just thawed
  1. Place sugar and water in a small saucepan over medium-low heat and stir until the sugar dissolves. Set aside to cool.
  2. Whisk the eggs and sugar syrup in a bowl to combine (do not overwhisk). Strain the mixture into a small jug.
  3. Preheat oven to 150°C. Use a 7cm-diameter fluted pastry cutter to cut 12 discs from the pastry. Line twelve 30ml (1 1/2-tbs) capacity patty pans with the pastry discs. At this stage I popped my pastry lined patty pans in the freezer for a few minutes to firm them up. I think this stops the pastry from puffing up in the oven too much.
  4. Divide the egg mixture among the pastry cases. Bake in oven for 20 minutes or until the custard is set and the pastry is light golden. Serve warm or at room temperature.

Then we all lay on the couch holding our fat tummies. But, we are pleased to say that we highly recommend all of these recipes.

item.title: Super Bowl Sunday Guacamole
item.dc:creator: Andrew Hunter
item.description: The countdown to the Super Bowl has officially started. My brother-in-law, Eddie, who is a 5th generation Texan, is staying home through the weekend to avoid the crazy crowds. He typically also stays away from the kitchen, but on this most sacred game day, Eddie ties on his annual apron strings and makes his signature guacamole. He’s not alone in his love for avocados, though he calls them “gator pears.” Did you know that 53.5 million pounds of avocados will be consumed on Super Bowl Sunday? That’s nearly 6 ounces for every man, woman and child in the United States. It’s the avocado industry’s biggest day of the year. That said, it’s time to talk guacamole.

item.title: Natural Disasters
item.dc:creator: goldfish
item.description: I live in California, a state which the rest of the country laughably threatens will one day fall into the sea. Natural disasters aren’t really funny. At least, they ought not to be. I think people back east are just jealous of our awesome winters. While the rest of you are digging out your cars [...]

item.title: Dear prof, Let’s not use social media in the classroom. -Your students
item.dc:creator: Gemma
item.description: Don’t let the title of this post fool you- I am definitely an advocate for the use of social media and other types of new technology in the classroom. However, I am not a fan of professors using these technologies just for the sake of using them. Case in point: That lovely image you see above [...]
item.content:encoded:
Don’t let the title of this post fool you- I am definitely an advocate for the use of social media and other types of new technology in the classroom. However, I am not a fan of professors using these technologies just for the sake of using them. Case in point:

The abandoned blog

That lovely image you see above is a screenshot of the class blog for one of my graduate-level journalism courses.

Problem # 1: Infrequent updates. The date on the last post is January 17th. Today is February 3rd.


No updates

Problem # 2: Actually, the updates aren’t simply infrequent. There aren’t any updates! That post is the only post on the blog.

One lonely post

Problem #3: The content of that post is just our class syllabus, copy-and-pasted, word for word.

Just a syllabus

Problem #4: School has been in session for three weeks. There are over 20 students in this class. Take a closer look at the whopping number of followers on this blog:

Please follow me!

No comments, no discussion, no followers. It’s just a static page with our class syllabus slapped on it.

Before you go thinking that we’re a bunch of lazy, uninspired students, let me assure you that we’re not. This is a master’s program we’re in- most if not all of the students are highly committed and take their work very seriously.

The reason there is no participation on the blog is because we also use the Blackboard Learning System. Our syllabus, announcements, assignments and grades are posted there. Our conversations take place on the discussion boards. Heck, even our research papers can be submitted through Blackboard.

As you can see, there is a high level of participation on our discussion boards (45 messages):

Let me make it clear that I hold this professor and my university in high esteem, and this post is not intended as a sign of disrespect. I hope my intentions aren’t misconstrued because I genuinely believe in the excellence and quality of my master’s program.

I just want teachers to know that they don’t need to feel pressured into using every kind of new technology- blogs, wikis, Facebook, Twitter- in a desperate attempt to keep us engaged. A new educational tool should only be used if it somehow enhances the learning environment and contributes something of value to the students. And it’s much better to just stick to one new technology tool and use it really well rather than try to use everything just to keep up with the times.

After all, being digitally literate includes the ability to…

  • critically evaluate the myriad of new technology tools constantly being created;
  • select the ones best suited for your needs; and
  • judge when it’s appropriate to incorporate one of these new tools in your teaching method or just stick to traditional methods.

So, if blogging is what you do best, go ahead and set up a class blog. If Facebook is what seems to be reaching your students, use it. And, if just standing in front of a class and talking is the best way that you get your point across, then give us an old-fashioned lecture- we’re all ears.

item.title: bangkok; an escape
item.dc:creator: Vivian
item.description: Hong Kong has been unseasonably cold. Since it usually hovers around 12-15 degrees in the winter, nobody bothers to get central heating – including the student residence I’ve been staying in. So trying to do work of any kind during single-digit weather in a non-heated apartment building is just unnecessary cruel and unproductive. Which is [...]
item.content:encoded:
on the boat; The Peninsula Bangkok

Hong Kong has been unseasonably cold. Since it usually hovers around 12-15 degrees in the winter, nobody bothers to get central heating – including the student residence I’ve been staying in. So trying to do work of any kind during single-digit weather in a non-heated apartment building is just unnecessary cruel and unproductive.

Which is why my friends and I decided to go on an impromptu four-day trip to Bangkok, Thailand – where it’s warm and sunny and provides an escape from the rhythm of classes and schoolwork. We booked our flights and hotels five days before leaving – probably the most spontaneous thing I’ve ever done (it trumps the spontaneity mentioned in this post, for sure). But it was so well worth it!

Here’s a very brief snapshot:

skyview; flight to Bangkok

I’ve never liked flying much (I mean, you’re literally forced to sit in a capsule for hours while being hurdled through the sky at high altitudes), but there’s still something about lift-off that makes me stare out the window like a kid.

woven flowers; market

Aren’t these beautiful? People weave these flowers into the most gorgeous ornaments and garlands. I believe they are used for religious purposes.

palm trees; Chaktuchak

Before arriving in Hong Kong, I had never been to a tropical climate before, which is why palm trees are still a huge novelty for me.

people praying; Grand Palace

Such a beautiful and magical place. I think we spent half the day there.

charms; street market

Really fun knick-knacks and charms to buy at street markets here. Perfect for someone who likes making their own jewellery!

rope-woven animals; street market

man weaving with rope; street market

Aren’t these amazing? It was really cool seeing them get handmade right in front of you.

pina colada; The Peninsula Bangkok

We didn’t actually stay there, being on a student budget and all, but we did get to enjoy drinks by the water. We had to leave before it actually got dark though, for fear of being eaten alive by mosquitoes.

I had an amazing time, and would like to go back to Thailand at some point to visit the Phuket and the islands. But one thing at a time – I’m actually in Japan right now (Echigo-Yuzawa, to be exact).

Cheers!

item.title: What’s for lunch today? Priorities.
item.dc:creator: scorpiomoon
item.description: Not unlike most offices, I have a few of coworkers who go out for lunch practically every day.  I’ve often wondered how they could afford to do that; not that I begrudge them the luxury, I just think it would get pretty expensive to eat out every day.  Then I would remember that they’re married; [...]
item.content:encoded:
Not unlike most offices, I have a few of coworkers who go out for lunch practically every day.  I’ve often wondered how they could afford to do that; not that I begrudge them the luxury, I just think it would get pretty expensive to eat out every day.  Then I would remember that they’re married; and therefore, they likely have more disposable income than I do. 

 As a perpetually single woman, there have been many times throughout my life when I’ve thought that having a husband would make things a lot easier.  Like the time that a large tree branch fell onto my roof and then bounced off leaving a hole in my roof.  Moving that branch was not easy!   Finding someone to fix the hole in my roof at a reasonable price was even more difficult.  Or there was the time that I went to my basement only to discover that I now had an indoor pool.  That would have been great if only it hadn’t been filled with backed up storm sewer water and it hadn’t ruined my water heater.  Whether it’s having the extra funds to go out for lunch or dealing with the cost of home repairs, there are definitely times when I’ve thought that having a partner to help shoulder the burden of maintaining a household would make life so much easier.  In theory anyway.  

 Recently my boyfriend and I decided that it was time to give cohabitating a try.  At about the same time, my friend was married in Las Vegas.  I was honored when she asked me to stand up with her.  Although I couldn’t really afford to go, I didn’t want to miss my best friend’s wedding.  So I sucked it, paid for the trip with a credit card and flew to Vegas.  (Paying for a trip with a credit card is not a good idea, I know, but that’s a story for another time.)    

Almost a month after her wedding, my friend and I were chatting about the difficulties of relationships.  After living alone for most of my adult life, I hadn’t expected living with someone to easy, but, as it turns out, it is even harder than I had expected.  Off handedly my friend noted that she thinks it was crazy when people change their relationship status to “it’s complicated” on Facebook.  “All relationships are complicated,” she said.  No kidding.   

Having a significant other doesn’t make everything better; it makes everything different.  Being married, having someone to shoulder the burden, doesn’t take away all the problems.  It may help with some financial strains, but isn’t money one of the primary reasons couples get divorced?  Not to mention the fact that it also opens up a whole new category of problems that have absolutely nothing to do with money. 

Okay, yes, I realize that this ‘revelation’ should be obvious.  And it is.  But when you’ve struggled making ends meet your whole life there are times when being able to eat out for lunch every day seems like a really nice idea.  It sounds trivial, I know, but our perceptions can become a bit skewed when we’re on the outside looking in.  The funny thing is that, after giving it some thought, I realized that even if money wasn’t a concern, I can think of many things that I’d rather buy with my hard earned dollars than lunch at a restaurant.  Luckily, I have great friends who are there to help me remember what’s really important in life and it’s not lunch.

item.title: The Ultimate Square (in the making)
item.dc:creator: square_one
item.description: Because it’s not vanity at age four… and even if it is later on, who cares? A solid pep talk in front of the mirror is healthy every now and then : ) The only things she doesn’t like? The wailing baby in the background stealing her spotlight, bad hair days, and her uncanny resemblance [...]
item.content:encoded:
Because it’s not vanity at age four… and even if it is later on, who cares? A solid pep talk in front of the mirror is healthy every now and then : )

The only things she doesn’t like? The wailing baby in the background stealing her spotlight, bad hair days, and her uncanny resemblance to a certain rat I mean pop country singer. Oh hey, I just found this pic of Taylor Swift! Check it out:

 

Now there’s someone who hasn’t been looking in the mirror recently….

media:content.media:title: Buck toothed beauty Taylor Swift has a very bad hair day as she parodies her teenage self 1

item.title: In your face, Winter!
item.dc:creator: Gordon Runkle
item.description: Yes, it’s Winter — cold, snow, etc.  Happens every year. So what are you going to do about it?  Listen to some TV news crew hyping it up as thought it was the end of the world as we know it?  (Snomageddon — yes, very  clever, very droll.)  Cower in your cave house, venturing out [...]
